titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller (Nelson A.) personal papers, Hugh Morrow Interviews, Series Q
A Guide to the Nelson A. Rockefeller personal papers, Hugh Morrow Interviews, Series Q FA352
titlestmt.author: Amy R. Fitch

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-02-01 05:05:39 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Nelson A. Rockefeller personal papers, Hugh Morrow Interviews, Series Q

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in three subseries:
Subseries 1 - Interviews with Nelson A. Rockefeller, Subseries 2 - Interviews with Nelson A. Rockefeller Associates and Family Members, and Subseries 3 - Restricted material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the transcripts of interviews conducted by Nelson A. Rockefeller's associate Hugh Morrow during two distinct time periods, as designated in the subseries. Morrow variously had served as Rockefeller's press secretary, speech writer, and director of communications beginning in 1960. No tapes of the interviews were saved after they were transcribed. There are no indices to the individual transcripts. Subseries 3 contains material with access restrictions that is not open to research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The transcripts are arranged in the chronological order of the interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Between July and November 1977, Hugh Morrow conducted 12 interviews with Nelson A. Rockefeller for the purpose of eventually coauthoring a biography of Rockefeller.

The subject matter varies greatly both within and among the interviews. However, the topics most widely discussed by Rockefeller are his interests and activities related to Latin America and his insights on the state of the nation and the world during and immediately following World War II. The topics of art and his interest in collecting recur as well. Rockefeller also provides his detailed impressions of several of the U.S. Presidents under whom he served or against whom he campaigned: Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon B. Johnson, and Richard M. Nixon. In the final interview (Folder 12), Rockefeller reflects on his tenure as Vice President in the Ford Administration. To some extent, throughout the interviews he also discusses his family, his childhood, and significant influences on his life while he was growing up.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this first of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses early family and childhood stories about his siblings, particularly his brother Laurance. Other topics included family travels to the western United States and to Europe; childhood interactions with his father, John D. Rockefeller Jr.; his relationship with his mother, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller; Abby's relationship with John Jr.; Nelson's interactions with his grandfather, John D. Rockefeller Sr.; and experiences at the Lincoln School and at Dartmouth College. Lastly he goes into his early years after college, his marriage to Mary Todhunter Clark, jobs at Rockefeller Center and Chase Manhattan Bank, and then his first experiences in Washington, DC, as President Franklin Roosevelt's Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Restricted material - Documents living Rockefeller family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the second of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses childhood family life, homes, his interest in furnishings and landscaping, and collecting. Other topics include his initial work with Henry Kissinger, Alger Hiss, President Eisenhower's administration, the 1955 Geneva Summit, and the development of the Open Skies program. He gives background on the Act of Chapultepec, his effort to include Argentina in the United Nations, the establishment of the Organization of American States (OAS), and the origins of the Rio Pact. Lastly, he goes into the origins and work of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund (RBF) Special Studies project, followed by his motivation to run for elected office and the 1958 Republican ticket for New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the third of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses influences on his life, such as a strong Baptist philosophy and sense of social responsibility. He details the Rockefeller family and its tradition of keeping account ledgers, as well as the Aldrich family and history of art collecting, leading into his perspective on family philanthropies. Other topics include the influences of nurses, tutors, and governesses on his childhood; early summers in Maine; Dartmouth College influences and activities (such as the Grenfell expedition); and summer travels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the fourth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses his deep appreciation of the visual arts, recounting his early activities with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), and collecting in general. Additionally, he describes his work with his father on the development of Rockefeller Center followed by a short stint with Chase Manhattan Bank. He also mentions his Standard Oil activities and other business ventures in Venezuela and Mexico. He concludes with discussion of his children.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Restricted material - Documents living Rockefeller family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the fifth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller recalls his early work with Rockefeller Center and its leasing agreements with RCA, NBC, and RKO. He continues with discussion of his years at the Lincoln School of Columbia University's Teacher's College, and then later his role on a parents committee as the school was closed down. He concludes with a narrative of the origins of his interest in Latin America and his first trips to Venezuela in 1937 and 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the sixth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller continues with his interest in Latin America (as first described in the August 4 transcript in Folder 5). He details the inspiration for his memorandum to President Franklin Roosevelt on the significance of the growing threat of Nazi influence in Latin America. That memo led to the creation of the Office of Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, which Mr. Rockefeller led for four years and describes in this transcript.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Restricted material - Documents living Rockefeller family members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the seventh of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses his career in the Roosevelt Administration as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs and his impressions of President Roosevelt. He continues with description of the state of the federal government leading into World War II and then concludes with remarks about his time in the Eisenhower Administration as Special Assistant to the President for Foreign Affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the eighth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller recalls his relationships with members of the Roosevelt family. He also describes the 1966 gubernatorial campaign in New York, when he won his third term. He then continues with his impressions of the Roosevelt Administration and Washington leading up to World War II, as well as the conference to create the United Nations in 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the ninth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller provides his perspectives on several members of the Roosevelt Administration. He then continues with descriptions of the personnel and activities of the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs (OCIAA).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the tenth of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses the conference to establish the United Nations that was held in San Francisco in April 1945, by which time he was Assistant Secretary of State for American Republic Affairs. He continues with his work after World War II, including as president of the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), as board chair of Rockefeller Center, and as Under Secretary of the U.S. Department of Health, Education, and Welfare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the eleventh of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses his impressions of the U.S. Presidents under whom he served, as well as their closest aides. This transcript covers, in the following order, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Harry S. Truman, John F. Kennedy, Lynden B. Johnson, and Richard M. Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the last of 12 interviews with Hugh Morrow, Nelson Rockefeller discusses his impressions of President Gerald R. Ford and briefly of President Richard M. Nixon. He continues with details on his term as Vice President in the Ford Administration and concludes with description of events during the 1976 Republican National Convention.

did.unittitle: Interviews with NAR Associates and Family Members

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The first 24 transcripts in this subseries are organized alphabetically by the last name of the individual being interviewed. The next 29 are in order by when they were opened for research. The remaining folders are alphabetized by last name, except for the final folder.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Following Nelson A. Rockefeller's death in January 1979, Hugh Morrow conducted interviews with Rockefeller's former associates and family members to document the memories of those people who had significant working and personal relationships with him. Between August 1979 and September 1980, Morrow interviewed 76 individuals. All but one of the interviews were tape recorded; Morrow made a transcript of the one unrecorded interview from his notes. A few interviews were summarized by Morrow, while all others were transcribed verbatim. The recording tapes were not saved.

Many of the interviewees are deceased but not all. Editing was completed on several transcripts, but others have handwritten notations of correction. The folder list includes the interviewees' relevant positions, dates of interviews, and page counts.

Throughout the transcripts, topics range from politics to art and from foreign policy to family relationships and philanthropy. There is a heavy emphasis on Rockefeller's three presidential and four gubernatorial campaigns from 1958 to 1970. A number of the interviews also focus on New York State government programs and administration. Additionally, in some interviews there is discussion of Latin America and the organizations and programs that Rockefeller established or enhanced for that region of the globe. The transcripts are most useful as indications of how these individuals viewed particular issues and interacted with Nelson Rockefeller and his staff or family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kissinger met Nelson Rockefeller while serving on the staff of the Quantico II conference in the mid-1950s. He then joined the staff of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund Special Studies. Under President Richard Nixon, he served first as National Security Advisor and then as Secretary of State, a position he continued during President Gerald Ford's administration. Vice President Rockefeller and he regularly collaborated during those years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Starting as a member of the staff of Room 5600 in the 1960s, she then joined the research staff for political campaigns. She also served on the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations and the Critical Choices Commission. She was one of Nelson Rockefeller's executors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New York State Republican Chair

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lawyer, Room 5600

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Served in several advisory capacities to Nelson Rockefeller, including Assistant Counsel to the Governor; Deputy Counsel to the Vice President; personal counsel; Rockefeller Brothers Fund Trustee; and executor for Margaretta F. Rockefeller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Architect who worked closely with Nelson Rockefeller, starting with the latter's years as Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs during World War II and continuing through his four terms as Governor of New York.
